keyTakeAways: The internet’s reliance on a few dominant cloud providers like AWS makes it vulnerable to outages, even if they are brief.
The root cause of the outage was a failure in the Domain Name System (DNS), which prevented access to data stored in AWS’s DynamoDB service.
AWS is not immune to technical faults, and past outages suggest a lack of redundancy in critical internet infrastructure.
The impact of such outages is widespread, affecting banking, social media, e-commerce, and airline booking platforms.
Experts warn that the internet's centralized architecture contradicts its original decentralized design, leading to cascading failures.
The frequency of major outages shows insufficient redundancy and competition among cloud providers.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A major outage of Amazon Web Services (AWS) disrupted thousands of internet services globally, including banking, shopping, and social media platforms, due to a failure in the Domain Name System (DNS) that prevented access to AWS’s DynamoDB and EC2 services. The outage, which lasted several hours and affected users worldwide, particularly on the US East Coast, underscores the fragility of the internet’s current infrastructure, which relies heavily on a small number of cloud providers. Experts note that while AWS has not experienced such outages frequently, the concentration of critical services in a few cloud regions makes the system vulnerable to cascading failures. Past incidents, such as the 2024 CrowdStrike software glitch and AT&T’s network meltdowns, highlight similar vulnerabilities. Experts argue that the internet’s original decentralized design has been compromised by centralization, and without stronger redundancies or competition among cloud providers, such outages will continue to impact global digital operations.
title: The internet just had another global outage. Why does this keep happening?
